column1: Varel ([ˈfaːʁəl]) is a town in the district of Friesland
column3: Germany. It is situated near the Jade River and the Jade Bight
column4: approximately 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) south of Wilhelmshaven and 30 kilometres (19 mi) north of Oldenburg.

column1: The castle church is the oldest building in Varel. The first part of the church is believed to have been built in 1144. The tower was added between 1200 and 1250
column3: which were rebuilt in today's form first in 1651 and then in 1737.  The altar
column4: font and pulpit were carved in 1613 – 1618 by Ludwig Münstermann. The altar is nearly 10 metres (33 ft) high and is one of the main works of Northern German Mannerism.

column2: the patron saint was Saint Peter. Today
column3: the castle church is a Lutheran church

column1: The church was formerly one of the buildings of the castle
column2: which was demolished in the 19th century soon after a fire destroyed most parts of it.
